{{Infobox person | image =Harvey Samuel Firestone by Underwood c1910.jpeg | image_size = | caption =Harvey Firestone (c. 1910) | birth_date ={{birth date|1868|12|20|mf=y}} | birth_place =[[Columbiana, Ohio]], U.S. | death_date ={{death date and age|1938|2|7|1868|12|20|mf=y}} | death_place =[[Miami Beach, Florida]], U.S. | occupation =Founder of [[Firestone Tire and Rubber Company]] | spouse =[[Idabelle Smith Firestone]] | children = Harry (April 12–16, 1897)
[[Harvey S. Firestone, Jr.|Harvey, Jr.]] (1898–1973)
Russell (1901–1951)
[[Leonard Firestone|Leonard]] (1907–1996)
Raymond (1908–1994)
Roger (1912–1970)
Elizabeth (1914–1941) }} [[Image:Ford Edison Firestone1.jpg|thumb|right|200px|[[Henry Ford]], [[Thomas Edison]], [[Harvey Firestone]]. [[Ft. Myers]], [[Florida]], February 11, 1929.]] [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 102-12257, Harvey Firestone.jpg|thumb|200px|Firestone in 1931]] '''Harvey Samuel Firestone''' (December 20, 1868 – February 7, 1938) was an American businessman, and the founder of the [[Firestone Tire and Rubber Company]], one of the first global makers of automobile tires. ==Family background== Firestone was born on the [[Columbiana, Ohio]] farm built by his paternal grandfather. He was the second of Benjamin and Catherine ([[née]] Flickinger) Firestone's three sons; Benjamin had a son and a daughter by his first wife. The original farm was disassembled and moved to [[Greenfield Village]], a {{convert|90|acre|m2|adj=on}} historical site founded by [[Henry Ford]], in 1983 as part of a larger outdoor museum. Firestone's paternal great-great-great-grandfather, Hans Nicholas Feuerstein, immigrated from [[Berg, Bas-Rhin]], [[France]],[http://familytreemaker.genealogy.com/users/f/r/a/Scott-O-Fraser/FILE/0022page.html Familytreemaker.genealogy.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120212063747/http://familytreemaker.genealogy.com/users/f/r/a/Scott-O-Fraser/FILE/0022page.html |date=2012-02-12 }} in 1753, and settled in [[Pennsylvania]].[http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~mysong/p1670.htm "Shirer Family Genealogy Project, Person Page 1670" ''ancestry.com''] October 18, 2010 Three of Nicholas' sons – including Harvey's great-great-grandfather, Johan Nicholas – changed their surname to "Firestone", the English translation of the family's German name "Feuerstein".[http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~mysong/p1687.htm "Shirer Family Genealogy Project, Person Page 1687" ''ancestry.com''] October 18, 2010 On November 20, 1895, Firestone married [[Idabelle Smith Firestone|Idabelle Smith]].[http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~mysong/p11749.htm "Shirer Family Genealogy Project, Person Page 11733" ''ancestry.com''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121102191137/http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~mysong/p11749.htm |date=2012-11-02 }} October 18, 2010 They eventually had seven children. Notable great-grandchildren include: [[Andrew Firestone]], [[Nick Firestone]], and [[William Clay Ford, Jr.]] (the son of Henry Ford's grandson and Harvey and Idabelle's granddaughter [[Martha Firestone Ford|Martha]]). ==Education and career== After graduating from [[Columbiana High School]], Firestone worked for the [[Columbus Buggy Company]] in [[Columbus, Ohio]] before starting his own company in 1890, making [[rubber]] tires for [[carriage]]s. In 1900 he soon saw the huge potential for marketing tires for automobiles and then founded the [[Firestone Tire and Rubber Company]], a pioneer in the mass production of tires. In 1926 he published a book, ''Men and Rubber: The Story of Business'', which was written in collaboration with [[Samuel Crowther (journalist)|Samuel Crowther]].''Men and Rubber: The Story of Business''. By Harvey Samuel Firestone, in collaboration with [[Samuel Crowther (journalist)|Samuel Crowther]]. London: William Heinemann & Co., printed in U.S.A., 1926. ==Death== In 1938, Firestone died of [[coronary thrombosis]].{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |title=Harvey Firestone is Dead in Florida. Rubber Manufacturer Dies in Sleep at His Miami Beach Estate. He Was 69 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1938/02/08/archives/harvey-firestone-is-dead-in-florida-rubber-manufacturer-dies-in.html |quote=Harvey S. Firestone, a farm boy who built one of the largest rubber businesses in the world, died of a coronary thrombosis as he slept early today in the great mansion of Harbel Villa, an ocean-front estate he acquired in 1924. He was 69 years old. |publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=February 8, 1938}} ==The Millionaires' Club== Firestone, [[Henry Ford]], and [[Thomas Edison]] were generally considered the three leaders in American industry at the time, and often worked and vacationed together.{{cite web |last=Zumbrun |first=Francis Champ |title=Famous Travelers - Edison, Ford and Firestone |publisher=Maryland Department of Natural Resources |url=http://www.dnr.state.md.us/feature_stories/FamousTravelersPart1.asp |accessdate=February 4, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130203060801/http://www.dnr.state.md.us/feature_stories/FamousTravelersPart1.asp |archivedate=February 3, 2013 |df= }} All three were part of a very exclusive group titled "The Millionaires' Club." ==Legacy== The main library of [[Princeton University]] is named [[Firestone Library]] in his honor. It is among the largest university libraries in the world. On August 3, 1950, the [[Harvey S Firestone Memorial]], a large sculpture ensemble dedicated to Firestone, created by sculptors [[James Earle Fraser (sculptor)|James Earle Fraser]] and [[Donald De Lue]] was dedicated. It is located at Bridgestone Firestone Inc., 1200 Firestone Parkway in [[Akron, Ohio]]. In 1974, Firestone was inducted into the [[Automotive Hall of Fame]]. [[Firestone High School]] in [[Akron, Ohio]], is named in his honor. There is a Harvey S Firestone Park in [[Columbiana, Ohio]]. The town [[Harbel]] in [[Liberia]], home to Firestone's rubber plantation, the largest in the world, is named after Firestone and his wife Isabelle. ==See also== * [[Firestone Stadium]] * [[Harvey S. Firestone Memorial]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category}} *[http://www.firestone.com/ Firestone Tires] *[http://www.bridgestoneamericas.com/corporate/history/index.html Firestone Tires' History] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20140714163621/http://btr360.com/2014/07/01/22-business-ideas-from-harvey-firestone/ Harvey Firestone: Where the Rubber Meets the Road] *{{IMDb name|id=1304843|name=Harvey Firestone}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060928175459/http://www.academyofachievement.org/honorees/harvey_firestone.htm Academy of Achievement's biography on Firestone] *[http://www.infoplease.com/ce6/people/A0818742.html Info Please biography on Harvey Firestone] *[http://www.nndb.com/people/788/000086530/ NNDB biography on Harvey Firestone] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060830081312/http://www.automotivehalloffame.org/honors/index.php?cmd=view&id=58&type=inductees Automotive Hall of Fame biography on Harvey Firestone] *[http://epe.lac-bac.gc.ca/100/205/301/ic/cdc/industrial/firestone.htm About Firestone Canada] *[http://firestone1753.weebly.com/ Firestone Roots in Alsace] *{{findagrave|grid=339}} * {{PM20|FID=pe/005196}} {{Bridgestone Corporation}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Firestone, Harvey}} [[Category:1868 births]] [[Category:1938 deaths]] [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:Firestone family]] [[Category:People from Columbiana, Ohio]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Akron, Ohio]] [[Category:Tire industry people]] [[Category:Deaths from thrombosis]] [[Category:Henry Ford family]] [[Category:Automotive pioneers]] [[Category:American people of French descent]] [[Category:American people of German descent]] [[Category:American people of Austrian descent]] [[Category:Asheville School alumni]] [[Category:Deaths from coronary thrombosis]]

page.title: High School of Art and Design

revision.text:
{{distinguish|The High School of Music & Art}} {{Infobox school | name = High School of Art and Design | latin_name = | logo = http://www.artanddesignhs.com/ | seal_image = | image = Hs-art-design.jpg | alt = High School of Art and Design building | caption = | location = | address = 245 East 56th Street | city = [[Manhattan]] | state = [[New York (state)|New York]] | zipcode = 10022 | country = [[United States]] | coordinates = {{coord|40.759025|N|73.966082|W|format=dms|display=inline,title|type:edu_region:US-NY_scale:10000}} | type = [[State school|Public]] | established = November 8, 1936 | oversight = [[New York City Department of Education]] | principal = Manuel A. Ureña <ref>[http://www.artanddesignhs.org/ "Principal's Message"]</ref><ref>[http://www.artanddesignhs.org/staff_directory "Staff Directory - High School of Art and Design"]</ref> | grades = [[Ninth grade|9]]–[[Twelfth grade|12]] | campus type = Urban | slogan = | conference = [[Public Schools Athletic League]] | school logo = | colors ={{Color box|blue|border=darkgray}}{{Color box|gold|border=darkgray}} Blue and Gold | website = [http://www.artanddesignhs.org/ artanddesignhs.org] | footnotes = }}
The '''High School of Art and Design''' is a [[Career and Technical Education]] [[high school]] in [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]]. Founded in 1936 as the School of Industrial Art, the school moved to 1075 Second Avenue in 1960 and more recently, its [[Midtown Manhattan]] location on [[56th Street (Manhattan)|56th Street]], between [[Second Avenue (Manhattan)|Second]] and [[Third Avenue (Manhattan)|Third Avenue]]s,<ref>{{google maps|url=https://www.google.com/maps/place/high+school+of+art+and+design/@40.758986,-73.966038,15z/data=!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0x5c6e14e0bbb634c6?sa=X&ei=mIhHVbupKI2rogSx84CABw&ved=0CJEBEPwSMA4|title=High School of Art and Design, 245 E 56th St, New York, NY 10022|access-date=May 5, 2015}}</ref> in September 2012. High School of Art and Design is operated by the [[New York City Department of Education]].
==History== On November 8, 1936,<ref name="PR-6Nov04">{{cite press release |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=1,000 Expected to Rally at Art & Design High School on Monday, November 8th |url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2004/11/prweb175560.htm |location=New York |publisher=New York City |date=November 6, 2004 |agency=PRWeb.com |accessdate=2014-01-06}}</ref><ref name="Yearbook hist 1960p16">{{cite book|title=SIA Fresco '60|publisher=(Yearbook) The Board of Education of the City of New York|page=16|chapter=S.I.A — 257 West 40th Street |url=http://www.tads39.fotki.com/yearbooks/1960_sia_yearbook/60page016.html#media|accessdate=7 January 2014}}</ref> four art teachers began what was to become the High School of Art and Design, the '''School of Industrial Art''',<ref name=NYC-Dept-of-Ed>{{cite web | url=http://schools.nyc.gov/ChoicesEnrollment/High/Directory/school/?sid=3212 | title = Art and Design High School > Did You Know? | publisher = [[New York City Department of Education]] | accessdate= 2013-11-26}}</ref> in a former [[Manhattan]] elementary school at 257 West 40th Street,<ref name="Yearbook hist 1960p16" /> which for a time had housed a [[Works Progress Administration|WPA]] [[Federal Theatre Project]] locale.<ref name="Yearbook hist 1960p13">{{cite book|title=SIA Fresco '60|page=13|chapter=History of S.I.A|url=http://www.tads39.fotki.com/yearbooks/1960_sia_yearbook/60page013.html#media|accessdate=7 January 2014}}</ref><ref name= "ArtEmphasis">{{Citation |author=Mira Tweti |date=December 5, 2001 |title=School's Alumni and Staff Feel Its Art Emphasis Is Neglected|work= [[The New York Times]] |page=D8 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/12/05/nyregion/school-s-alumni-and-staff-feel-its-art-emphasis-is-neglected.html |accessdate=January 6, 2014}}</ref> Initially, they used orange crates and plywood to make storage and desks.<ref name= "ArtEmphasis"/> One of the co-founders, John B. Kenny, became principal in 1941.<ref>{{cite news|title=John Kenny, 88, Dies; Founded High School|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/03/02/obituaries/john-kenny-88-dies-founded-high-school.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|date= March 2, 1988|accessdate=6 January 2014}}</ref> The school soon moved to a building on East [[79th Street (Manhattan)|79th Street]] in the [[Upper East Side]], the former annex to the [[Benjamin Franklin High School (New York City)|Benjamin Franklin High School]].<ref name="Yearbook hist 1960p14">"History of S.I.A", [http://www.tads39.fotki.com/yearbooks/1960_sia_yearbook/60page014.html#media p. 14]</ref> In September 1960, the school changed its name to the High School of Art and Design and moved to 1075 Second Avenue in east [[Midtown Manhattan|Midtown]].<ref name= "ArtEmphasis"/>
The 1936 school was first envisioned as a [[Continuation high school|continuation school]], that is, a school where children who had left school and gotten jobs attended for half days to continue their education, normally including vocational classes relevant to their current or possible future jobs. However, it opened as a vocational high school,
On November 8, 2004, a rally was scheduled on the occasion of the school's 68th anniversary. This was to include a press conference at which increased support of the school would be urged.<ref>{{citation needed|date=February 2018}}</ref> On November 8, 2006 the school celebrated its 70th anniversary. The office of the [[Mayor of New York City]] issued a proclamation making November 8 "High School of Art and Design Day".<ref>{{citation needed|date=February 2018}}</ref>
==Academics and events== Applicants must take an entrance exam and present a portfolio to be accepted. Freshmen sample all art and design subjects before selecting a major for their sophomore, junior and senior years. Students at Art and Design receive two periods of art instruction per day, choosing from among eight art majors: cartooning, animation, architecture, graphic design, illustration, fashion, photography, and film/video.
Art and Design's Kenny Gallery, named for the school's founding principal John B. Kenny, hosts monthly art exhibits of student work. The gallery is open to the public. The Black Box Theatre was donated by the Friends of Art and Design (FAD).<ref>{{Citation |author=Anemona Hartocollis |publication-date=December 13, 2000 |title=From a Rude Bump, a Lift for a School |work= [[New York Times]] |page=B11 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2000/12/13/nyregion/from-a-rude-bump-a-lift-for-a-school.html|accessdate=January 6, 2014}}</ref>
==Notable people==
===Faculty=== Some members of the school's faculty became notable for their creative work outside teaching. These include: *Daisy Aldan, poet, actress, editor and translator<ref>[https://jacket2.org/article/daisy-aldan-new-folder "On Daisy Aldan, 'A New Folder' | Jacket2] "After taking degrees at Hunter College and Brooklyn College, she spent thirty-five years teaching at New York’s School of Industrial Art, where her students included Art Spiegelman, Tony Bennett, Calvin Klein and Harvey Fierstein, as well as Warhol associates Gerard Malanga and Jackie Curtis."</ref> *[[Irv Docktor]], fine artist and book illustrator<ref>[https://irvdocktor.smugmug.com Irv Docktor website]</ref> *[[Frank Eliscu]], designer and sculptor of the [[Heisman Memorial Trophy]] and other works of art<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/07/nyregion/frank-eliscu-83-who-sculptured-heisman-trophy.html NY Times ''Frank Eliscu, 83, Who Sculptured Heisman Trophy'']</ref><ref>[http://rivals.yahoo.com/ncaa/football/blog/dr_saturday/post/Finding-Ed-Smith-NYU-fullback-Heisman-inspirat?urn=ncaaf-271571 Yahoo News ''Who really posed for the Heisman Trophy''] Retrieved September 22, 2010</ref> *[[Alvin Hollingsworth]], comic book illustrator and fine artist<ref>[http://strippersguide.blogspot.com/2012/02/ink-slinger-profiles-ac-hollingsworth.html ''Stripper's Guide: Ink-Slinger Profiles: A.C. Hollingsworth'']</ref> *[[Bernard Krigstein]], painter, illustrator, cartoonist<ref name=Newsarama>{{cite web | last=Arrant | first=Chris | date = June 7, 2010 | url =http://www.newsarama.com/comics/larry-hama-beyond-gi-joe-100607.html | title =Looking Back With Larry Hama - Beyond G.I. Joe| publisher= [[Newsarama.com]]}}</ref> *[[Tom Wesselmann]], [[pop art]]ist, famous for his "Great American Nude" series<ref>[https://www.widewalls.ch/artist/tom-wesselmann/ "Biography of Tom Wesselmann | Widewalls"], October 10, 2016. "After he successfully established himself as one of the leading artists in NYC, Tom began to teach art at a public school in Brooklyn and later at the High School of Art and Design."</ref>
===Alumni=== {{refimprove|section, with several of the names listed here, |date=January 2014}} {{div col|colwidth=40em}} * '''1937''': [[Paul Winchell]], ventriloquist, inventor, actor<ref name=YouTubeInterview>{{cite web|last=Michaud|first=John|title=Paul Winchell Smurfs Gargamel & Tigger Cartoon Voices Interview 2004|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gt7ow-W8UZQ|accessdate=1 December 2012|quote=I went out to California in 1938. I was a kid going to school in NY city and I was studying commercial art. I went to a school called the [[School of Industrial Art]] in Manhattan.}}</ref> * '''1940''': [[Violet Barclay]], a pioneering female comic book artist<ref name=comicartville>{{cite news |last=Vassallo |first=Michael J. |url=http://www.comicartville.com/bellman.htm |title=A Timely Talk with Allen Bellman |publisher=Comicartville.com |year=2005 |page=[http://www.comicartville.com/bellmanpg2.htm 2] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5lYfiHjIi?url=http://www.comicartville.com/bellmanpg2.htm |archivedate=November 25, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> * '''1940''': [[Al Plastino]], comic book illustrator, writer and editor<ref name=newsday2012>{{cite news|url=http://www.newsday.com/lifestyle/retirement/long-islanders-behind-batman-comics-1.3909300 |title=Long Islanders behind Batman comics |date=August 16, 2012 |first=Daniel |last=Bubbeo |work=[[Newsday]] |location=New York/Long Island |pages=B4-B5 |accessdate=August 18, 2012 |archivedate=August 19, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6A1cYrIyN?url=http://www.newsday.com/lifestyle/retirement/long-islanders-behind-batman-comics-1.3909300 |deadurl=no |df= }} {{subscription}}</ref> * '''1940''': [[Chic Stone]], comic book illustrator<ref name=jkconline>Stone in {{cite news|last=Cassar |first=James |url=http://www.twomorrows.com/kirby/articles/14stoneint.html |title=Excerpts from Chic Stone interview |work=Jack Kirby Collector |issue=14 |date=February 1997 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wKFHitns?url=http://www.twomorrows.com/kirby/articles/14stoneint.html |archivedate=February 7, 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> * '''1941''': Allen Bellman, comic book artist <ref>[https://www.lambiek.net/artists/b/bellman_allen.htm Lambiek Comiclopedia, Comic Creators</ref><ref>[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Violet_Barclay] "Barclay attended the School of Industrial Art high school, where her classmates included future comic-book professional Allen Bellman."</ref> * '''1943''': [[Carmine Infantino]], comic book artist, editor, member Comic Book Hall of Fame<ref name="Groth">{{cite web|url= http://archives.tcj.com/2_archives/i_infantino.html|title=Carmine Infantino|accessdate=2007-06-24|author=Gary Groth|publisher=The Comics Journal |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070207230211/http://www.tcj.com/2_archives/i_infantino.html |archivedate = 2007-02-07}}</ref><ref name=DialBForBlog>Kimball, Kirk. [http://www.dialbforblog.com/archives/489/ "Gaspar Saladino — The Natural"]. Dial B for Blog Retrieved February 11, 2012.</ref> * '''1943''': [[Helmut Krone]], art director<ref>[http://designobserver.com/article.php?id=4657 ''Helmut Krone, Period.'']</ref> * '''1943''': [[Henry Wolf]], graphic designer, art director and photographer<ref>[http://www.howardgreenberg.com/artists/henry-wolf Howard Greenberg Gallery]</ref><ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2005/02/16/business/media/henry-wolf-graphic-designer-and-photographer-dies-at-80.html ''Henry Wolf, Graphic Designer and Photographer, Dies at 80'']</ref> * '''1944''': [[Joe Orlando]], comic book illustrator, [[Mad (magazine)|Mad magazine]] Associate Publisher<ref name=DialBForBlog/> * '''1945''': [[Tony Bennett]], singer and painter<ref name=NYT20011205>Tweti, Mira. [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A07EED7163CF936A35751C1A9679C8B63 "School's Alumni and Staff Feel Its Art Emphasis Is Neglected"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', December 5, 2001. Accessed October 29, 2007. "Graduates include the designer Calvin Klein, the singer Tony Bennett, the playwright Harvey Fierstein and the filmmaker Ralph Bakshi."</ref> * '''1945''': [[Joe Giella]], comic book illustrator<ref name=lambiek>[http://www.lambiek.net/artists/g/giella_joe.htm "Joe Giella"]. Kees Kousemaker's [[Lambiek Comiclopedia]]. Retrieved February 11, 2012.</ref><ref name=NYT20010610/> * '''1946''': [[Sy Barry]], comic book illustrator<ref name=NYT20010610>Fischler, Marcelle S. [https://www.nytimes.com/2001/06/10/nyregion/long-island-journal-cartoonists-gather-to-celebrate-real-life.html "LONG ISLAND JOURNAL; Cartoonists Gather to Celebrate Real Life"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', June 10, 2001. Accessed January 22, 2017. "Mr. Scaduto, Mr. Giella, Mr. Barry and Mr. Squelio attended the School of Industrial Art, now the School of Art and Design, together in the 1940's."</ref> * '''1946''': [[Vladimir Kagan]], furniture designer<ref>Staff. [https://www.nytimes.com/1983/10/09/nyregion/long-island-journal-211618.html "Long Island Journal"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', October 9, 1983. Accessed January 22, 2017. "'A very special class,' it was called in 1946, the year that 279 art students graduated from the School of Industrial Art in New York City.... Among those scheduled to attend from the original class were Vladimir Kagan of New York City, the interior designer; Al Scaduto of Jericho, a cartoonist for the syndicated comic strip ''They'll Do It Every Time''; Alex Toth of Los Angeles, also a cartoonist; Sal Tortora of Mattituck, a watercolorist, and Serafin Soto of Huntington, an architect and painter."</ref> * '''1946''': [[Al Scaduto]], syndicated cartoonist<ref name=NYT20010610/> * '''1947''': [[Alex Toth]], comic book illustrator, animator for Hanna-Barbera<ref name=DialBForBlog/> * '''1947''': [[John Romita, Sr.]], comic book illustrator<ref name=DialBForBlog/> * '''1950''': [[Dick Giordano]], comic book illustrator<ref name=DialBForBlog/> * '''1951''': [[Leo and Diane Dillon|Leo Dillon]], adult and children's book illustrator<ref>[https://www.hbook.com/1976/08/authors-illustrators/leo-and-diane-dillon/ "The Horn Book"]</ref> * '''1951''': [[Bill Kresse]], syndicated cartoonist<ref>[http://www.odwyerpr.com/story/public/1786/2014-01-27/bill-kresse-longtime-odwyers-illustrator-dies.html "Bill Kresse, Longtime O'Dwyer's Illustrator, Dies"], [[O'Dwyer's]], January 27, 2014. Accessed January 22, 2017. "Kresse was born June 17, 1933 in Brooklyn. His art career began immediately after graduating Brooklyn's High School of Industrial Arts, when he got a job illustrating for famed animation studio Terrytoons, which created many popular cartoons of the post-war era, including ''Mighty Mouse,'' ''Heckle and Jeckle,'' ''Deputy Dawg,'' and ''The Mighty Heroes.''"</ref> * '''1952''': [[Eva Hesse]], minimalist painter and sculptor<ref>[https://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/feminist_art_base/eva-hesse Eva Hesse], [[Brooklyn Museum]]. Accessed January 22, 2017. "Eva Hesse was born 1936, in Hamburg, Germany. Her family fled the Nazis and arrived in New York in 1939 where she attended the School of Industrial Art, then Pratt Institute in Brooklyn in 1952, and Cooper Union from 1954 to 1957."</ref> * '''1952''': [[Sam Scali]], advertising-agency owner<ref>[http://adcglobal.org/hall-of-fame/sam-scali/ "Sam Scali : ADC • Global Awards & Club"]</ref> * '''1953''': [[Peter Hujar]], photographer<ref>[http://www.blouinartinfo.com/artists/89446-peter-hujar Peter Hujar], [[Blouin Artinfo]]. Accessed January 22, 2017. "In the late 1940s, Hujar enrolled at the School of Industrial Art and found a mentor in poet Daisy Aldan."</ref> * '''1953''': [[Ronald Wayne]], Apple Computer co-founder<ref>[https://www.cultofmac.com/304686/ron-wayne-apple-co-founder/ The Cult of Mac], December 2014. "He trained as a technical draftsman at the School of Industrial Art in New York."</ref> * '''1955''': John Anthony (Gianantonio Iorio), fashion designer<ref>[http://www.fashionmodeldirectory.com/designers/john-anthony/ Fashion Model Directory] "While attending the High School of Industrial Arts, he was awarded a scholarship to the Accademia d'Arte in Rome, Italy."</ref> * '''1955''': [[I. C. Rapoport]], photojournalist<ref>[http://icrapoport.com/the-early-years-part-1-1955-1957/ The Early Years – Part 1], [[I. C. Rapoport]], April 1, 2016. Accessed January 22, 2017. "I had, a year earlier, entered the High School of Industrial Art in Manhattan, and having no desire to join the photography program offered there, studied what my brother Mel had studied, advertising design."</ref> * '''1956''': [[Ralph Bakshi]], animator, filmmaker<ref>Culhane, John. [https://www.nytimes.com/1981/03/22/arts/ralph-bakshi-iconoclast-of-animation.html "Ralph Bakshi - Iconoclast of Animation"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', March 22, 1981. Accessed January 22, 2017. "From being a poor student at Thomas Jefferson High School, he was inspired to compete for one of 10 openings at the School of Industrial Art (now the High School of Art and Design), a vocational school for commercial artists. When he graduated in June of 1956, he won the school's cartooning medal - and he has been transmuting the gritty reality of the streets in drawings ever since."</ref> * '''1956''': [[John Johnson (reporter)|John Johnson]], TV news anchor, author and painter{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} * '''1956''': Sheila Metzner, fashion, portrait and landscape photographer<ref>[http://adcglobal.org/hall-of-fame/sheila-metzner/ "Sheila Metzner : ADC • Global Awards & Club"]</ref> * '''1956''': [[Barbara Nessim]], illustrator and educator<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20150906014824/http://www.bgc.bard.edu/images/content/1/6/16368.pdf Barbara Nessim: An Artful Life], [[Bard College]]. Accessed January 22, 2017. "Born in the Bronx, Barbara Nessim studied at New York's School of Industrial Art (now the High School of Art and Design) and attended Pratt Institute from 1956 to 1960."</ref> * '''1956''': Regina Porter, fashion designer<ref>[http://articles.mcall.com/1992-02-13/topic/2842141_1_linens-regina-porter-jeans "'Natural' Sportswear From Porter"] February 13, 1992. Accessed January 22, 2017. "Born and raised in New York City, Porter studied at the High School of Art and Design and the Fashion Institute of Technology."</ref> * '''1957''': [[Bobby Weinstein]], songwriter, member of the [[Songwriters Hall of Fame]]<ref>[http://www.songwritershalloffame.org/exhibits/bio/C356 Bobby Weinstein], [[Songwriters Hall of Fame]]. Accessed January 22, 2017. "Bobby Weinstein, was a product of a musical family, attended the High School of Art and Design in Manhattan, but his allegiance to the arts soon took a different turn when he became swept up by the Doo Wop music phenomenon which had swung into high gear at the time."</ref> * '''1957''': [[Phoebe Gilman]], children's book author and illustrator * '''1959''': [[Neal Adams]], comic book illustrator<ref name=DialBForBlog/> * '''1960''': [[Calvin Klein (fashion designer)|Calvin Klein]], fashion designer<ref name=NYT20011205/> * '''1960''': [[George Kuchar]], cult filmmaker and director<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/08/movies/george-kuchar-underground-filmmaker-dies-at-69.html "George Kuchar, Underground Filmmaker, Dies at 69" ''[[The New York Times]]'' September 8, 2011]</ref> * '''1960''': [[Antonio Lopez (illustrator)|Antonio Lopez]], fashion illustrator<ref name="smithsonian">{{Citation| title = Antonio Lopez & Juan Ramos| publisher = Smithsonian Institution| url = http://latino.si.edu/virtualgallery/antonio/bios.htm| accessdate = 2009-12-04}}</ref> * '''1960''': [[Gerard Malanga]], poet, photographer and filmmaker<ref>[http://www.godine.com/book-author/gerard-malanga/ "Gerard Malanga - David R. Godine, Publisher"]</ref> * '''1960''': [[William T. Williams]], abstract painter <ref>[http://africanah.org/in-collection-william-t-williams/ Afrikanah.org]</ref> * '''1961''': [[Robert Volpe]], painter and [[NYPD]] detective, the "Art Cop"<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/05/nyregion/05volpe.html "Robert Volpe, Art-Theft Expert, Dies at 63"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', December 5, 2006.</ref> * '''1962''': [[Roscoe Orman]], actor, author and artist, best known as "Gordon" on Sesame Street * '''1962''': [[Simon Gaon]], painter * '''1963''': [[Ronnie Landfield]], abstract painter * '''1963''': [[Joey Skaggs]], media prankster, performance artist * '''1963''': [[Michael Steiner (artist)|Michael Steiner]], abstract artist and sculptor * '''1963''': [[Jim Simon (artist)|Jim Simon]], animator and artist<ref name="tads39.fotki.com">{{cite web| title= James A. Simon |publisher= (photo entry) 1963 High School of Art and Design Yearbook (Art & Design Alumni Association)|date= 1963|page=23|url=http://www.tads39.fotki.com/yearbooks/1963_ad_yearbook/ | accessdate =October 24, 2016|archivedate=November 15, 2011 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20111115131200/http://tads39.fotki.com/yearbooks/1963_ad_yearbook/| deadurl=no}}</ref> * '''1965''': [[Jackie Curtis]], Warhol film star, poet, playwright<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=AMizCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT12&lpg=PT12&dq=Jackie+Curtis+high+school+of+art+and+design&source=bl&ots=66F78SS76D&sig=CH_LZ5cKkX2foTJwl7U7b5gTp9E&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwii29vI8r7OAhVIHx4KHUoWAXkQ6AEIMTAE#v=onepage&q=Jackie%20Curtis%20high%20school%20of%20art%20and%20design&f=false ''Superstar in a Housedress: The Life and Legend of Jackie Curtis'']</ref> * '''1965''': [[Art Spiegelman]], Pulitzer Prize winning author and cartoonist<ref>D'Arcy, David (July 13, 2011). [http://www.theartnewspaper.com/articles/Art-goes-back-to-school/24328 "Art goes back to school"]. ''[[The Art Newspaper]]''.</ref> * '''1967''': [[Bert Monroy]], digital art pioneer, author of books on Photoshop, Illustrator * '''1967''': [[Eric Carr]] (Paul Charles Caravello), drummer in the rock band [[Kiss (band)|Kiss]] * '''1967''': [[Frank Brunner]], comic book illustrator<ref name=Newsarama/> * '''1967''': [[Larry Hama]], writer and comic book illustrator<ref name=Newsarama/><ref name=DialBForBlog/> * '''1967''': [[Ralph Reese]], comic book illustrator<ref name=Newsarama/> * '''1967''': [[Lenny White]], jazz-funk drummer, member of [[Return to Forever]] * '''1967''': [[Terry Winters]], abstract painter and printmaker<ref>Kastner, Jeffrey. [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9501E1DF163EF93AA2575BC0A9679C8B63 "ART/ARCHITECTURE; An Energetic Imagist Who Dances With Chance"]. ''The New York Times''. August 19, 2001. Accessed November 19, 2007.</ref> * '''1968''': [[Candida Royalle]], producer and director of couples-oriented erotic films<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/11/movies/candida-royalle-maker-of-x-rated-films-dies-at-64.html "Candida Royalle, 64, Dies; Filmed Erotica for Women"] ''[[The New York Times]]'', September 10, 2015.</ref> * '''1968''': [[John Steptoe]], author and illustrator of children's books * '''1968''': [[Robin Tewes]], artist and painter * '''1968''': [[Frank Verlizzo]] ("Fraver"), Drama Desk Award-winning designer of theater art<ref>[http://www.ourtownny.com/city-arts-news/20150707/the-man-behind-the-image "The Man Behind The Image"], July 7, 2015</ref> * '''1969''': [[Pat Cleveland]], fashion model * '''1969''': [[Harvey Fierstein]], actor, playwright, gay activist<ref name=NYT20011205/> * '''1970''': [[Amy Heckerling]], film director, writer, actress<ref>Donadoni, Serena. [http://www2.metrotimes.com/editorial/story.asp?id=143 "Hormonal pyrotechnics 101: Amy Heckerling on life, love and other high-school explosives."] ''[[Metro Times]]''. July 26, 2000. Accessed February 10, 2008. "Few filmmakers are as in touch with their inner teenager as Amy Heckerling, even if her own experience is diametrically opposed to those of the California teens in her best films. The Bronx native attended the High School of Art and Design in nearby Manhattan, where she focused on photography, and eventually moved on to New York University to study film."</ref> * '''1971''': [[Lawrence Hilton-Jacobs]], actor and singer * '''1971''': [[Alan Kupperberg]], cartoonist and illustrator<ref>[http://www.lambiek.net/artists/k/kupperberg_a.htm Alan Kupperberg] at the [[Lambiek Comiclopedia]]. Accessed Apr. 4, 2009.</ref> * '''1971''': [[Steven Meisel]], fashion photographer<ref>[https://www.widewalls.ch/artist/steven-meisel/ Biography of Steven Meisel | Widewalls]</ref> * '''1971''': [[Lynette Washington]], jazz vocalist * '''1973''': [[Lisa Jane Persky]], actress.<ref>[http://www.eclectica.org/v9n4/contributor_notes.html Contributor's Notes], ''[[Eclectica magazine]]'', October / November 2005. Accessed August 6, 2008. "Eljay Persky grew up in New York City's Greenwich Village, attending the High School of Art and Design."</ref> * '''1973''': [[Tom Sito]], animator, filmmaker, educator * '''1974''': [[Manny Vega]], painter, muralist, mosaicist * '''1976''': [[Marcelino Sanchez]], film and television actor * '''1976''': [[Tracy 168]] (Michael Tracey), graffiti artist * '''1976''': [[Mike Carlin]], comic book writer and editor<ref>Talon, Durwin S. [https://books.google.com/books?id=yVZ83qOSfrwC&pg=PA5&lpg=PA5&dq=Mike+Carlin,+High+School+of+Art+and+Design&source=bl&ots=XOMe8ez-ac&sig=sYivER84RK5zjl7rrhHUwmzojBo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=wzY3T-rlHerv0gG-srW9Ag&ved=0CD8Q6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=Mike%20Carlin%2C%20High%20School%20of%20Art%20and%20Design&f=true ''Panel Discussions: Design in Sequential Art Storytelling'']. [[TwoMorrows Publishing]]. November 1, 2007. [[Google Books]]. Retrieved February 11, 2012.</ref> * '''1977''': [[Joe Jusko]], comic book illustrator<ref name=DialBForBlog/> * '''1977''': [[Fab Five Freddy]], (Fred Brathwaite) hip hop pioneer, graffiti artist and filmmaker<ref>[http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/music_box/2017/06/remembering_mobb_deep_s_prodigy_dead_at_42.html "Mobb Deep’s Prodigy was hip-hop’s greatest poet of fear."] "Both attended New York’s prestigious High School of Art and Design, a school whose alumni include Calvin Klein, Amy Heckerling, Fab Five Freddy, and Marc Jacobs."</ref> * '''1977''': [[Gladys Portugues]], champion body builder * '''1978''': [[Lasana M. Sekou]], poet, journalist, author, publisher * '''1978''': [[Lorna Simpson]], artist and photographer * '''1978''': [[Lee Quiñones]], actor and graffiti artist * '''1978''': [[Malcolm Jones III]], comic book illustrator<ref name=ComicMix>Davis, Michael (August 8, 2008). [http://www.comicmix.com/news/2008/08/08/milestone-if-you-re-not-there-you-just-won-t-get-it-by-michael-davis/ "Milestone: If You're Not There, You Just Won't Get It: Straight No Chaser"]. [[ComicMix]]. Quote: "I knew (we all knew) that Malcolm was a troubled soul and I’m sad to say that when he committed suicide a few years ago I was not that surprised. [[Denys Cowan|Denys]] and I would often talk about how to deal with Malcolm and reached out to him many times. That does little to erase the feeling that we somehow let our friend down."</ref> * '''1979''': [[Denys Cowan]], comic book illustrator * '''1979''': [[Jimmy Palmiotti]], inker and writer of comic books, games and film<ref>Evans, Chris (April 3, 2010). [http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=25549 "WC10: Comic Writers Unite!"]. [[Comic Book Resources]].</ref> * '''1979''': [[Mark Texeira]], comic book illustrator<ref>[http://www.wizardworldcomiccon.com/marktexeira.html "Mark Texeria"]. [[WizardWorld]]. Retrieved February 11, 2012.</ref> * '''1980''': Chris 'Daze' Ellis, graffiti writer and artist <ref>[https://nypost.com/2016/08/11/meet-the-legendary-graffiti-artists-who-inspired-the-get-down/ Meet the legendary graffiti artists who inspired ‘The Get Down’]</ref><ref>[https://untappedcities.com/2015/11/18/street-artist-christopher-daze-ellis-reveals-solo-show-at-the-museum-of-the-city-of-new-york/ "Street Artist Christopher "Daze" Ellis Reveals Solo Show at The Museum of the City of New York"] ''Untapped Cities'', November 18, 2015.</ref> * '''1980''': [[Christopher Martin (entertainer)| Christopher Martin]], rapper and actor<ref>[https://www.celebritynetworth.com/richest-celebrities/richest-rappers/christopher-play-martin-net-worth/ "Christopher Play Martin Net Worth | Celebrity Net Worth"]</ref> * '''1980''': [[Nicole Willis]], singer/songwriter, visual artist<ref>https://nicolewillis.com/cv</ref> * '''1981''': [[Marc Jacobs]], fashion designer<ref>Le Marie, Nicole. [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/hot-on-pradas-heels-the-divine-marc-jacobs-437764.html "Hot on Prada's heels, the divine Marc Jacobs"]. ''[[The Independent]]''. February 25, 2007. Accessed April 18, 2008. "Since graduating from the New York High School of Art and Design in 1981 and moving on to the Parsons School of Design, the New Yorker has gathered accolades galore and is now artistic director for Louis Vuitton."</ref> * '''1982''': [[Lady Pink]] (Sandra Fabara), graffiti writer, artist and muralist.<ref>[http://thegalleriesatmoore.org/publications/lady.shtml "Femmes Fatales: An Installation by Lady Pink] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080604022945/http://www.thegalleriesatmoore.org/publications/lady.shtml |date=2008-06-04 }}. The Galleries at Moore. Accessed July 24, 2008.</ref><ref>[https://jerseyjoeart.com/2009/05/20/art-design-high-school-nyc/ Graffiti School – Art & Design High School (NYC)] "Mare 139 & Lady Pink in an Art & Design Bathroom (From Hip Hop Files)"</ref> * '''1983''': [[Mare139]] (Carlos Rodriguez), graffiti artist and designer<ref>[https://jerseyjoeart.com/2009/05/20/art-design-high-school-nyc/ Graffiti School – Art & Design High School (NYC)] "Mare 139 & Lady Pink in an Art & Design Bathroom (From Hip Hop Files)"</ref> * '''1983''': [[Matthew Waldman]], industrial designer<ref name="futurism into design">{{cite news|title=Nooka watch founder Waldman ties futurism into design of neon-colored gizmos, hopes to expand brand|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/life-style/fashion/nooka-watch-founder-waldman-ties-futurism-design-neon-colored-gizmos-hopes-expand-brand-article-1.960279|work=[[Daily News (New York)]]|date=October 6, 2011|accessdate=October 5, 2013}}</ref> * '''1985''': [[Roger Sanchez]], Grammy Award winning DJ, producer, recording artist<ref>[https://www.songkick.com/artists/524535-roger-sanchez "Roger Sanchez Tickets, Tour Dates 2018 & Concerts – Songkick"] "A graduate of New York City’s High School of Art and Design, Sanchez subsequently enrolled at the Pratt Institute studying architecture."</ref> * '''1986''': [[Pharoahe Monch]] (Troy Donald Jamerson), [[rapper|hip hop artist]]<ref>[http://hiphopgoldenage.com/artists/pharoahe-monch/ "Pharoahe Monch - Hip Hop Golden Age"]</ref> * '''1987''': [[Ivan de Prume]], former drummer in the groove metal band [[White Zombie (band)|White Zombie]]<ref>[https://www.pinterest.com/pin/502432902148961728/?lp=true Pinterest] "Ivan de Prume, NYC High School of Art and Design class of 1987, is a heavy metal drummer whose music became famous in the groove metal band White Zombie."</ref> * '''1990''': [[Jamal Igle]], comic book and animation storyboard artist<ref name=Pepose>Pepose, David (March 16, 2011). [http://www.newsarama.com/comics/artists-alley-12-jamal-igle-110316.html "Artist's Alley 12: Jamal Igle From Art School to ZATANNA"]. Newsarama.</ref><ref>[http://www.titanstower.com/source/libtt3t2/iglemultiverso.html "MULTIVERSO DC: Exclusive interview with Jamal Igle"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101013180238/http://www.titanstower.com/source/libtt3t2/iglemultiverso.html |date=2010-10-13 }}. Titans Tower. March 2008</ref> * '''1992''': [[Joe Madureira]], comic book illustrator<ref>[http://www.wizardworldcomiccon.com/joemamajowiw.html "Iconic X-Men Artist Coming to a City Near You!"] WizardWorld. Retrieved February 11, 2012.</ref><ref>[http://lambiek.net/artists/m/madureira_joe.htm "Joe Madureira"]. Kees Kousemaker's Lambiek Comiclopedia. Retrieved February 11, 2012.</ref> * '''1992''': [[Mobb Deep]], hip-hop duo<ref>[http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/music_box/2017/06/remembering_mobb_deep_s_prodigy_dead_at_42.html "Mobb Deep’s Prodigy was hip-hop’s greatest poet of fear."] "For starters, Prodigy and Havoc themselves weren’t exactly central-casting gangsters: Both attended New York’s prestigious High School of Art and Design, a school whose alumni include Calvin Klein, Amy Heckerling, Fab Five Freddy, and Marc Jacobs."</ref> * '''1998''': [[Fabolous]], rapper<ref>[https://allhiphop.com/2015/08/06/fabolous-talks-about-attending-art-school-connection-to-basquiat/ "Fabolous Talks About Attending Art School & Connection To Basquiat"] "Before I was a musician, I drew,” said Fabolous. “The housing projects in Brooklyn weren’t much of a canvas, people didn’t know that I had it in me – but I actually went to an art and design high school."</ref> * '''2006''': [[ASAP Ferg]] (Darold D. Brown Ferguson, Jr.), rapper and fashion designer<ref>[http://www.vogue.co.uk/article/tiffany-and-co-asap-ferg-brand-ambassador "A$AP Ferg On Breaking Down Boundaries As Tiffany & Co's Brand Ambassador"], ''[[Vogue.co.uk]]'', June 15, 2018.</ref> * '''2006''': [[Awol Erizku]],painter, photographer, sculptor, videographer<ref>[http://www.widewalls.ch/artist/awol-erizku/ Biography of Awol Erizku | Widewalls] "Erizku was born in 1988 in Ethiopia and grew up in South Bronx, New York where he attended Art and Design High School."</ref> {{div col end}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Hugo Van Vuuren | honorific_suffix = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = Hugo Van Vuuren, 2015.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Hugo Van Vuuren, May 2015 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1984}} | birth_place = [[Pretoria, South Africa]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | monuments = | residence = United States and South Africa | nationality = | other_names = | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = [[Harvard College]]
[[Harvard Graduate School of Design]] | occupation = Entrepreneur, Investor | years_active = 2006-present | employer = | organization = | agent = | known_for = | notable_works = | style = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = | height = | weight = | television = | boards = Work-Bench
Soldier Design | religion = | denomination = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | website = {{URL|hugovanvuuren.org}} | footnotes = }} '''Hugo Van Vuuren''' (born 1984) is a South African entrepreneur and investor. An expert-in-residence at the [[Harvard School of Engineering and Applied Sciences]], he is the co-founder of Work-Bench, an early stage enterprise technology venture fund.{{cite news|last1=Burstein|first1=David O.|title=The Xfund, Harvard, And The Student-Entrepreneur|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/1826202/xfund-harvard-and-student-entrepreneur|accessdate=4 May 2016|work=Fast Company|date=March 27, 2012}}{{cite web|title=Hugo Van Vuuren|url=https://cyber.law.harvard.edu/people/hugo|website=cyberlaw.harvard.edu|publisher=Harvard Berkman Center|accessdate=5 May 2016}} ==Early life and education== Van Vuuren was born in Pretoria, South Africa. In 2003, Van Vuuren began undergraduate studies at Harvard, and graduated with a BA in economics in 2007. He earned a master's degree in design studies from the Harvard Graduate School of Design in 2012.{{cite news|last1=Landry|first1=Lauren|title=How To Turn a Risk Into a Legacy|url=http://bostinno.streetwise.co/2013/03/01/how-to-turn-a-risk-into-a-legacy/|accessdate=5 May 2016|work=BostInno|date=January 27, 2012}} While pursuing his postgraduate degree, Van Vuuren was awarded [[fellow]]ships by the [[MIT Media Lab]], [[TED (conference)|TED]] and Pop Tech. He was a graduate student fellow at the [[Berkman Center for Internet & Society]] at Harvard University from September 2010 through May 2012, and a scholar at the [[Aspen Institute]] in 2011.{{cite web|title=The Communication Crises and the Evolution of Personal and Cultural Protocols|url=https://cyber.law.harvard.edu/events/luncheon/2011/04/vanvuuren|publisher=Berkman Center|accessdate=5 May 2016}}{{cite web|title=Aviva Presser Aiden and Hugo Van Vuuren|url=https://poptech.org/people/aviva_presser_aiden_and_hugo_van_vuuren|website=poptech.org|publisher=Pop Tech|accessdate=8 May 2016}} ==Career== ===Harvard Entrepreneurship=== At Harvard, Van Vuuren worked closely on art and science experiments and startup projects with professor David Edwards, whom he had first encountered in 2007 as student in Edwards' "Idea Translation" class. In 2008, along with several others in the class, Van Vuuren co-developed off-grid microbial fuel cells for use in sub-Saharan Africa. The research and project was funded by private investors, the Harvard Institute for Global Health, MIT IDEAS Global Challenge, as well as a $200,000 Lighting Africa grant from the World Bank and a [[Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation]] Challenges Grant.{{cite book|last1=Edwards|first1=David|title=The Lab: Creativity and Culture|date=October 31, 2012|publisher=Harvard University Press|location=Cambridge, MA|isbn=0674057198|pages=53–64, 142–146|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XizCTR5UArgC&pg=PA53&dq=hugo+van+vuuren&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi-oPyGmMHMAhVISiYKHX9cAqYQ6AEIHDAA#v=onepage&q=hugo%20van%20vuuren&f=false|accessdate=5 May 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Doty|first1=Cate|title=For Africa, ‘Energy From Dirt’|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/11/giving/11AFRICA.html|accessdate=5 May 2016|work=New York Times|date=November 10, 2008}}{{cite news|title=SEAS receives $100k Grand Challenges Explorations Grant|url=https://www.seas.harvard.edu/news/2011/04/seas-receives-100k-grand-challenges-explorations-grant|accessdate=5 May 2016|work=Harvard School of Engineering|date=April 28, 2011}} In 2009, Van Vuuren worked with Edwards to establish ArtScience Labs (also known as the Laboratory at Harvard). An interdisciplinary platform for idea experimentation and exhibition in the arts and sciences, it was modeled after Le Laboratoire, an experimental art and design center in Paris. Van Vuuren served as the lab's director from its 2009 launch until 2012. ===Experiment Fund=== Based on the growing ecosystem of startups at Harvard, and demonstrated in part by the success of the Lab, the Experiment Fund was founded in January 2012. A seed-stage investment fund co-founded and led by Van Vuuren, it was established specifically to support student start-ups and technologies and platforms created in Cambridge (or by people educated in Cambridge). The Experiment Fund was backed by Breyer Capital, Accel Partners, Polaris Partners, Harvard University, and NEA. Patrick Chung and Harry Weller, both NEA partners, were co-founders of the fund, as were Polaris' Alan Crane, and Jim Breyer of Breyer Capital. Edwards served as an advisor. The company's early investments included [[Kensho]], Philo (formerly Tivli), Zumper, and Rest Devices, among others.{{cite news|last1=Farrell|first1=Michael B.|title=Harvard makes space for venture capitalist|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2013/09/08/the-venture-capitalist-campus/uArvrYnGYzvyb9MUVfcQVP/story.html|accessdate=5 May 2016|work=Boston Globe|date=September 9, 2013}}{{cite news|last1=Huang|first1=Gregory T.|title=Harvard Experiment Fund, Backed by NEA, Joins Crowded Investor Field|url=http://www.xconomy.com/boston/2012/01/31/harvard-experiment-fund-backed-by-nea-joins-crowded-investor-field/#|accessdate=5 May 2016|work=Xconomy|date=January 31, 2012}}{{cite news|last1=Kirsner|first1=Scott|title=Harvard dreamer works to link art, science, commerce|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/business/2013/03/03/what-will-harvard-david-edwards-dream-next/chUZvx1Zb7QpgTMhsI2EhL/story.html|accessdate=5 May 2016|work=Boston Globe|date=March 3, 2013}} In 2014 Van Vuuren partnered with Chung to create Xfund. Focused on "technically gifted entrepreneurs with a liberal arts mindset,"{{cite news|last1=Chapman|first1=Lizette|title=Xfund Closes $100 Million Second Fund, Targets Student Entrepreneurs|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/venturecapital/2014/12/04/xfund-closes-100-million-second-fund-targets-student-entrepreneurs/|accessdate=5 May 2016|work=Wall Street Journal|date=December 4, 2014}} Van Vuuren left the company after a high-profile dispute with Chung. Chung filed a lawsuit, and Van Vuuren countersued. The suit was settled privately in 2016.{{cite news|last1=Primack|first1=Dan|title=Top of the Morning|url=https://www.axios.com/pro-rata-2493651882.html|accessdate=1 November 2017|work=Axios|date=October 6, 2017}} ===Work-Bench Ventures=== With Thomas Quinlan, the president and chief executive of [[RR Donnelly|RR Donnelly & Sons Company]] and Jonathan Lehr, a veteran of Morgan Stanley, Van Vuuren founded Work-Bench Ventures in early 2012. A New York-based enterprise technology VC fund, Work-Bench has invested in APX Labs, DialPad (formerly Switch), True Office, VTS, X.ai, and vArmour, among others.{{cite news|last1=Gage|first1=Deborah|title=Morgan Stanley Vet Builds Enterprise Startups With Work-Bench Ventures|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/venturecapital/2014/11/21/morgan-stanley-vet-builds-enterprise-startups-with-work-bench-ventures/|accessdate=5 May 2016|work=Wall Street Journal|date=November 21, 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Griffith|first1=Erin|title=Meet Work--Bench: New York's first "post-accelerator" program for enterprise startups|url=https://pando.com/2013/06/17/meet-work-bench-new-yorks-first-post-accelerator-program-for-enterprise-startups/|accessdate=5 May 2016|work=Pando|date=June 17, 2013}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.hugovanvuuren.org/ Official site] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Van Vuuren, Hugo}} [[Category:1984 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Venture capitalists]] [[Category:Harvard Graduate School of Design alumni]] [[Category:South African businesspeople]] [[Category:South African emigrants to the United States]]

revision.text:
'''Ivan Savnik''', [[Slovenes|Slovene]] industrialist and [[merchant]] (1879–1950) [[File:Ivan Savnik.JPG|thumb|right|160px|Ivan Savnik]] Ivan Savnik was a [[Slovenes|Slovene]] merchant and industrialist, one of the biggest manufacturers and retailers in [[Upper Carniola]] region of [[Slovenia]]. With his products he supplied merchants across [[Austria-Hungary]] and later [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]].http://www.kamra.si/Default.aspx?module=5&id=381 During the time of mayor Ciril Pirc he worked for many years as a councillor and advisor at the city council of [[Kranj]].http://www.kamra.si/Data/sub0/INDUSTRIALIZACIJAKRANJA.pdf He was also actively involved in the construction of the National Hall (Narodni dom) in [[Kranj]]. [[File:Postcard of Kranj (7).jpg|thumb|center|550px|Department store of Ivan Savnik on the main square in Kranj, 1930s]]
==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Savnik, Ivan}} [[Category:1879 births]] [[Category:1950 deaths]] [[Category:Slovenian businesspeople]] [[Category:People from Kranj]]

{{Infobox officeholder | name = Jean-Claude Bastos de Morais | office = | order = | image = Jean-Claude Bastos de Morais.jpg | imagesize = | caption = | birth_date = October 28, 1967 | birth_place = [[Fribourg]], Switzerland | nationality = [[Switzerland|Swiss]] & [[Angola]]n | occupation = {{plain list| *Entrepreneur *Chief Executive Officer }} | website = {{url|www.jeanclaudebastosdemorais.com}} }} '''Jean-Claude Bastos de Morais''' (born October 28, 1967 in [[Fribourg]])<ref name="A">{{cite web |url=https://www.srf.ch/sendungen/reporter/jean-claude-bastos-und-das-wunder-von-angola |title=Jean-Claude Bastos und das Wunder von Angola |author=Simon Christen |date=17 December 2017 |publisher=SRF |access-date=30 December 2017}}</ref> is a [[Switzerland|Swiss]]-[[Angola]]n entrepreneur<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/mfonobongnsehe/2017/11/03/how-swiss-angolan-investor-jean-claude-bastos-de-morais-plans-to-deliver-better-healthcare-in-africa/#27ea00fa28cf|title=How Swiss-Angolan Investor Jean Claude Bastos De Morais Plans To Deliver Better Healthcare In Africa|last=Nsehe|first=Mfonobong|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-11-03|language=en}}</ref> who has founded and led several businesses over the course of his career. Among these are Quantum Global Group, an international investment group with a particular focus on Africa<ref name=":0" /> and Banco Kwanza Invest, Angola’s first [[investment banking|investment bank]].
== Family == Jean-Claude Bastos de Morais was born on October 28, 1967 in Fribourg, Switzerland.<ref name="A" /> He is of bi-national heritage. His father is from Angola<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/mfonobongnsehe/2014/10/01/meet-the-swiss-tycoon-who-is-funding-african-innovation/#2d59e4006189 |title=Meet The Swiss Entrepreneur Who Is Funding African Innovation |author=Mfonobong Nsehe |date=1 October 2014 |publisher=Forbes |access-date=31 December 2017}}</ref> and his mother is Swiss, coming from an entrepreneurial family.<ref name="Niyi Aderibigbe">{{cite web |url=http://thenerveafrica.com/6211/jean-claude-de-morais-innovation-entrepreneurship-and-growth/ |title=GrowthCore with Jean-Claude de Morais: Innovation can speed up economic diversification and job creation in Africa |author=Niyi Aderibigbe |date=3 June 2016 |publisher=The Nerve Africa |access-date=31 December 2017}}</ref> His maternal grandfather was an industrialist in the watch industry<ref>{{cite web |url=https://trueafrica.co/article/jean-claude-bastos-de-morais-the-man-supporting-innovation-in-slums-with-money-and-expertise/ |title=Jean-Claude Bastos de Morais: the publicity-shy entrepreneur unleashing innovation in Angolan slums |author=Claude Grunitzky |date=6 December 2016 |publisher=True Africa |access-date=31 December 2017}}</ref> and invented the light inside the watch.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://newafricanmagazine.com/jean-claude-bastos-de-morais-africas-innovation-guru/ |title=Jean-Claude Bastos de Morais: Africa’s innovation guru |author=Regina Jane Jere |date=27 June 2017 |publisher=NewAfrican |access-date=31 December 2017}}</ref> According to Bastos, his late Angolan grandmother inspired him to establish the African Innovation Foundation in 2009.<ref name="Niyi Aderibigbe"/>
== Education and career == Bastos studied [[economics]] at the [[University of Fribourg]] and received a Master of Arts in Management.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.jeanclaudebastosdemorais.com|title=Jean-Claude Bastos de Morais|website=Jean-Claude Bastos de Morais|language=en|access-date=2017-07-11}}</ref> He financed his studies by starting a regional [[mergers and acquisitions]] business that sold small companies.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://thenerveafrica.com/6211/jean-claude-de-morais-innovation-entrepreneurship-and-growth/ |title=GrowthCore with Jean-Claude de Morais: Innovation can speed up economic diversification and job creation in Africa |author=Niyi Aderibigbe |date=3 June 2016 |publisher=The Nerve Africa |access-date=15 January 2018}}</ref> In 1989, Bastos joined [[Deloitte]] as a consultant and later Abegglen Management Partners. In 1995, he founded a venture capital company focused on Swiss [[Small and medium-sized enterprises|SMEs]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/mfonobongnsehe/2014/10/01/meet-the-swiss-tycoon-who-is-funding-african-innovation/#2d59e4006189 |title=Meet The Swiss Entrepreneur Who Is Funding African Innovation |author=Mfonobong Nsehe |date=1 October 2014 |publisher=Forbes |access-date=15 January 2018}}</ref>
In 2007, Bastos de Morais founded Quantum Global Group.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.africaninnovation.org/jc.bastos.html|title=Jean-Claude Bastos de Morais {{!}} African Innovation Foundation|last=|website=www.africaninnovation.org|access-date=2017-11-03}}</ref> He is Quantum's current [[Chief executive officer|Chief Executive Officer]].<ref name=":0" /> In 2008, Bastos de Morais founded Banco Kwanza Invest,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/mfonobongnsehe/2014/10/01/meet-the-swiss-tycoon-who-is-funding-african-innovation/ |title=Meet The Swiss Entrepreneur Who Is Funding African Innovation |author=Mfonobong Nsehe |date=1 October 2014 |publisher=Forbes |access-date=21 November 2017}}</ref> Angola's first investment bank.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/chriswright/2014/09/05/inside-angolas-sovereign-wealth-fund/ |title=Inside Angola's Sovereign Wealth Fund |author=Chris Wright |date=5 September 2014 |publisher=Forbes |access-date=21 November 2017}}</ref>
In 2015 he launched the hybrid innovation hub, Fábrica de Sabão<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fabricadesabao.co.ao/en/|title=Home - Fábrica de Sabão|website=Fábrica de Sabão|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-11}}</ref> (The Soap Factory) to support innovation projects in Angola. The hub is a collaboration with the government, which leases it its premises. Fábrica de Sabão was built as an inclusive model to enable marginalized communities to participate in sustainable enterprise such as urban manufacturing.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://thenerveafrica.com/6211/jean-claude-de-morais-innovation-entrepreneurship-and-growth/|title=GrowthCore with Jean-Claude de Morais: Innovation can speed up economic diversification and job creation in Africa|date=3 June 2016|work=The Nerve Africa|access-date=2017-07-11|language=en-US}}</ref>
==NGOs== In 2017, Bastos de Morais was elected an international council member, [[Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.belfercenter.org/person/jean-claude-bastos-de-morais|title=International Council: Jean-Claude Bastos de Morais|publisher=Harvard Kennedy School|accessdate=5 March 2017}}</ref>
== African Innovation Foundation == In 2009, he founded the African Innovation Foundation (AIF)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.africaninnovation.org|title=Home - African Innovation Foundation|website=www.africaninnovation.org|access-date=2017-07-11}}</ref> which aims to support sustainable projects in Africa. The Foundation's Innovation Prize for Africa (IPA) was launched in 2011 in cooperation with the [[United Nations Economic Commission for Africa]] (UNECA).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.innovationprizeforafrica.org|title=Innovation Prize for Africa|website=www.innovationprizeforafrica.org|access-date=2017-07-11}}</ref> In 2016 the Innovation Prize for Africa celebrated its 5th anniversary,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/06/16/africa/aif-prize-inventions-2016/index.html|title=The 10 best inventions from Africa|last=CNN|first=Katie Pisa and Sophie Morlin-Yron, for|work=CNN|access-date=2018-02-20}}</ref> and the AIF signed a [[Memorandum of understanding|Memorandum of Understanding]] (MoU) with the [[World Intellectual Property Organization]] (WIPO) for cooperation to support African innovators.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/wipo/26677844740|title=WIPO and African Innovation Foundation Sign Collaboration Agreement|work=Flickr|access-date=2018-02-20|language=en-us}}</ref> In February 2017 the AIF signed a MoU with the Botswana Innovation Hub to support innovations in [[Botswana]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://innovationprizeforafrica.org/news13-02-17.html|title=News 13-02-2017 - Innovation Prize for Africa|website=innovationprizeforafrica.org|access-date=2018-02-20}}</ref> In addition to the IPA, the AIF founded the ZuaHub, a platform that connects innovators with resources.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbcafrica.com/apo/2017/10/10/african-innovation-foundation-call-for-applications-innovation-prize-for-africa-2018-awards-investing-in-inclusive-innovation-ecosystems/|title=African Innovation Foundation - Call for Applications: Innovation Prize for Africa 2018 Awards “Investing In Inclusive Innovation Ecosystems” - CNBC Africa|date=2017-10-10|work=CNBC Africa|access-date=2018-02-20|language=en-US}}</ref> By 2017 the IPA had a database of over 6000 innovators from 51 African countries.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://riseafricarise.com/innovation-prize-for-africa-2017-pauline-mujawamariya-koelbl/|title=Innovation Prize for Africa 2017: An interview with Pauline Mujawamariya Koelbl|date=2016-12-18|work=Rise Africa Rise|access-date=2018-02-20|language=en-GB}}</ref>
=== African Law Library === The AIF also initiated the ''African Law Library'' (ALL). The project was launched on 28 November 2013 at the [[African Union]]'s headquarters in [[Addis Ababa]], [[Ethiopia]]. With ALL Bastos implemented his idea of an online portal offering access to a wide range of legal documents as well as law and governance texts from African countries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.globethics.net/news/all-news/-/asset_publisher/uK4o/content/african-law-library-launches|title=African Law Library launches - Ethics News - Globethics.net|website=www.globethics.net|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-20}}</ref> The [[HuffPost|Huffington Post]] reported that 'in June 2014 alone, more than 10,000 research sessions were initiated on the African Law Library platform'. In March 2015 over 4500 regional and national court cases, 3600 legislative acts and 8000 secondary sources from eight African countries were published online.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/amolo-ngweno/democratizing-access-to-l_b_6580880.html|title=Democratizing Access to Legal Information -- For Every African|last=Ng'weno|first=Amolo|date=2015-02-03|website=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-20}}</ref>
== Philanthropic activities == In October 2011 Bastos founded the Kitangana Tennis Project for orphans in Angola.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gsb.uct.ac.za/jean-claude-bastos-de-morais|title=Mr Jean-Claude Bastos de Morais|website=www.gsb.uct.ac.za|language=en|access-date=2018-05-28}}</ref> In 2017, his Quantum Global Group sponsored the Muhr Awards for Arab films at the [[Dubai International Film Festival]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thriveglobal.com/stories/20791-diff-2017-features-emirati-cinema-jean-claude-bastos-de-morais-cate-blanchett-and-patrick-stewart-grace-the-event|title=DIFF 2017 features Emirati cinema, Jean Claude Bastos de Morais, Cate Blanchett, and Patrick Stewart grace the event|website=www.thriveglobal.com|language=en|access-date=2018-05-28}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://dubaifilmfest.com/en/news/25/151442/diff_welcomes_quantum_global_to_sponsor_the_prestigious_muhr_awards.html|title=Dubai International Film Festival {{!}} NEWS 2018|website=Dubai International Film Festival|access-date=2018-05-28}}</ref> In addition, Bastos supports several Universities. He sponsors a research project at the Center of Neuroscience ZNZ, a collaboration between the [[University of Zurich]] and the [[ETH Zurich|Swiss Federal Institute of Technology ETH]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.globethics.net/-/meet-our-authors-jean-claude-bastos-de-morais-switzerland-and-angola|title=Meet our authors - Jean-Claude Bastos de Morais, Switzerland and Angola - Ethics News - Globethics.net|website=www.globethics.net|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-28}}</ref> He also serves on the advisory board of the Event Letterari Monte Verita Festival, the Official Monetary and Financial Institutions Forum (OMFIF) and the [[University of Cape Town Graduate School of Business]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gsb.uct.ac.za/jean-claude-bastos-de-morais|title=Mr Jean-Claude Bastos de Morais|website=www.gsb.uct.ac.za|language=en|access-date=2018-05-28}}</ref>
==Corruption allegations== In 2011 he was convicted together with his partner{{who|date=November 2017}} by a criminal court in Switzerland for "repeated qualified criminal mismanagement". Both have illegally paid out money in an investment company under their control, which partly lined their own pockets.<ref>Christian Brönnimann: [https://interaktiv.tagesanzeiger.ch/2017/paradise-papers/angola-bastos/?openincontroller ''Wie ein Schweizer von Angolas Milliarden profitiert.''] Tages-Anzeiger, 5. November 2017.</ref> In 2017 the conviction played a major role in public discussions of his business activities which were uncovered by journalists in the [[Paradise Papers]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-41906123|title=Tycoon made $41m from ‘people’s fund’|last=Meisel|first=Anna|date=2017-11-07|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-05-28|last2=Grossman|first2=David|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.srf.ch/play/tv/rundschau/video/swiss-connection-spiel-mit-angolas-milliarden?id=a4d0c7af-eb28-46f1-8b4c-d5804e3a5dfe&station=69e8ac16-4327-4af4-b873-fd5cd6e895a7|title=Swiss Connection: Spiel mit Angolas Milliarden - TV - Play SRF|website=Play SRF|language=de|access-date=2018-05-28}}</ref><ref>Panama Papers, Leaks reveal extensive siphoning of $5bn Angolan sovereign wealth fund, 2016: {{cite web |url=https://panamapapers.investigativecenters.org/angola/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-05-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160529034238/https://panamapapers.investigativecenters.org/angola/ |archivedate=29 May 2016 |df= }}</ref>
== Angola sovereign wealth fund == In November 2017 the [[BBC News]] reported about him in relation to the [[Paradise Papers]].<ref name="demorais">{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-41906123|title=Paradise Papers: Tycoon made $41m from 'people's fund'|last=|first=|date=|website=BBC News|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-11-07}}</ref> The Paradise Papers reported his use of Angola's [[sovereign wealth fund]] for his own investment projects.<ref name="par">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/nov/07/angola-sovereign-wealth-fund-jean-claude-bastos-de-morais-paradise-papers|title=Angola sovereign wealth fund's manager used its cash for his own projects|author=David Left|date=7 November 2017|work=The Guardian|accessdate=19 November 2017}}</ref> After the Paradise Papers were leaked<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/nov/07/angola-sovereign-wealth-fund-jean-claude-bastos-de-morais-paradise-papers|title=Angola sovereign wealth fund's manager used its cash for his own projects|last=Pegg|first=David|date=2017-11-07|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-10-17}}</ref> licenses of seven funds of Bastos' Quantum Global were suspended on Mauritius after a visit of Angolan officials.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-04-09/suspended-mauritian-funds-said-to-be-linked-to-angolan-founder|title=Mauritius Suspends Quantum Funds After Angola Official Visit|last=|first=|date=2018-04-09|website=Bloomberg|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-17}}</ref> The Mauritius Supreme Court froze 519 million USD on 58 bank accounts of Quantum Global in early April 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-04-10/mauritius-is-said-to-freeze-519-million-of-quantum-s-assets|title=Mauritius Freezes $519 Million of Quantum’s Assets|last=|first=|date=2018-04-10|website=Bloomberg|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-17}}</ref> In London a British court froze 3 billion USD on Quantum Global accounts at the end of April 2018.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-07-24/son-of-ex-angolan-president-seeks-to-overturn-u-k-freeze-order|title=Ex-Angolan Leader’s Son Seeks Overturn of Freeze Order|last=|first=|date=2018-04-28|website=Bloomberg|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-17}}</ref>
At the end of July 2018 the freezing of British bank accounts was lifted by London's [[High Court of Justice|High Court]]. It ruled, that the freezing was based on false information. The court accused the state funds representatives of "breaches of the duty of disclosure" in the fund's application for a freezing and called this breaches "substantial" and "culpable".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-angola-swf-litigation/uk-judge-lifts-asset-freeze-order-against-quantum-global-in-angolan-swf-case-idUKKBN1KL1W9|title=UK judge lifts asset freeze order against Quantum Global in Angolan...|last=Milhench|first=Claire|work=U.K.|access-date=2018-10-17|language=en-GB}}</ref>
In September 2018 Bastos was arrested in Angola.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-45640818|title=Ex-president's son detained over 'fraud'|last=Meisel|first=Anna|date=2018-09-25|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-10-17|language=en-GB}}</ref> Quantum Global accused Angola of coercion and intimidation to forces Bastos to surrender assets.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/d9ce0e80-c5b4-11e8-8167-bea19d5dd52e|title=Angola accused of coercion in holding head of Swiss investment group|last=|first=|date=2018-10-01|website=Financial Times|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-17}}</ref>
==Writing== *He is the co-editor of the book ''Innovation Ethics. African and Global Perspectives'',<ref>http://www.globethics.net/documents/4289936/13403236/GE_Global_7_web.pdf/8d19e8ab-de35-4fd9-ad87-6deac077d3fc</ref> co-published by Globethics.net and the AIF. The book looks at innovation ethics and the “ethical innovator,”<ref>{{Cite book|title=Innovation Ethics|last=Jean-Claude Bastos de Morais|first=Christoph Stückelberger|publisher=Global Ethics.net|year=2014|isbn=978-2-88931-003-6|location=Geneva|pages=70, Innovation Ethics for Value-based Innovation, Christoph Stückelberger}}</ref>{{clarify|date=November 2017}} from multidisciplinary and international perspectives with a focus on Africa. *''The Convergence of Nations: Why Africa’s Time Is Now'', OMFIF Press,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.omfif.org/shop/the-convergence-of-nations-why-africas-time-is-now/|title=The Convergence Of Nations: Why Africa's time is now |publisher=OMFIF Press |year=2015|website=www.omfif.org|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-07-11}}</ref> in collaboration with a team of 31 authors from 15 nations on how Africa can benefit from changes in the world political and economic environment. *''SEED'' is a collaboration with the African Innovation Foundation (AIF), a Swiss-registered foundation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.globalinnovationexchange.org/organizations/african-innovation-foundation|title=African Innovation Foundation|website=www.globalinnovationexchange.org|language=en|access-date=2017-07-11}} </ref> ''SEED'' was published to reinforce the value and benefit of seeding innovation in all fields of development for a rich and prosperous Africa.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.biztechafrica.com/article/aif-launches-commemorative-book/11481/|title=AIF launches commemorative book|work=BiztechAfrica|access-date=2017-07-11}}</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jean-claude-bastos-de-morais/ *http://www.itnewsafrica.com/2015/05/what-if-african-nations-operated-as-one-big-innovation-ecosystem/ *http://www.euromoney.com/Article/3112458/Angola-fund-launch-leaves-questions-unanswered.html *http://www.jeanclaudebastosdemorais.com - personal website *http://www.quantumglobalgroup.com — website of Quantum Global Group *http://www.africabusinesscommunities.com/index.php/rss-abc-interviews/201082-jean-claude-bastos-de-morais-quantum-global-group-how-to-do-business-in-africa
